comments.body: We probably don't need to print this out each time - there generally won't be deleted files.
Long term I agree but I'm making the default output verbose until more users say this is stable.
Perhaps batch this up for fewer writes? `if ((complete % 10) == 0) ...`
Put this in globals.dart?
I kind of want globals.dart to die so I wanted to keep it local to where it is actually used.
What is the plan here with respect to changes on the VM side? Are you intending to make these changes?

I currently don't have the intention to jump in the Dart VM as there are other things I need to fix to make Flutter work for Windows. However, I am going to file an issue linking to the code bits here to make sure this doesn't get forgotten.

Do you want to do the changes on the VM side? :)
Filed https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/8502
Technically, this should be `file.fileSystem.path.canonicalize()`, though I doubt it'll ever matter (it would matter if `directory` is owned by a file system other than `fs`).
Why not inline the check and since you're bailing out here, just assume `packageExists == true` in the code below?
`packageExists` is mutable and changed lower down
printTrace for debugging? can it be removed?

Not sure what are the guidelines for printTraces, but I think this one is helpful - between it and next `printTrace('Update files')` we can see for example how much time is spent in actual compilation.
Should this be ` final var invalidatedFiles = <String>[];`
I believe the Flutter style guide suggests to always have variable type explicitly spelled out.

Wouldn't you want to use the deviceUri.path member (or some combination of members) here instead of converting it to a string and comparing the prefix?  Seems like you're throwing out the point of using a URI, which is that it gets parsed into its constituent parts so that things like hostname resolution and ports can be abstracted out.
No, I'm looking for a complete prefix match. If the deviceUri has a prefix match only looking at paths, but differs in any other property, I want to return in as is.
Similarly a TODO here that this clone will not be needed once we switch hot restart to use the IKG
Done
Doesn't this depend on the value passed in to `--output-dill`?   e.g. in Google, we're going to build the .dill file to a different location.
/cc @keertip
What does the 'dynamic' return type of deleteFile mean, what is the meaning of expected type of String->dynamic mean? Does this cast always hold?
+1 - is it coming in as `Map<dynamic, dynamic>`?  Can we specify so instead of `dynamic`?
The return type for `deleteFile` is `dynamic`, nothing more specific. Looking at the implementations of the api, the cast does hold, return type is either `Null` or `Map`.
Same question here
same as above, the api returns `Future<dynamic>`.
I thought success and count/bytes should be tracked and updated independently. Basically, you might want to report number of synced bytes even if whole operation ultimately failed.
Not sure how useful that is to report stats on a failed operation.

Here we just count and faithfully make aggregated results available for consumer to report them if they decide it's useful.
When synchronization failed, I can see how number of transferred bytes can be interesting to know especially if it's large number.
Maybe add a method `DevFSContent.copyToFile(File dst)`. Then its implementation in `DevFSFileContent` can use `File.copySync()`, which avoids sucking the file contents into the Dart heap.
nit: is "module" part of Dart's terminology? Or is it referring to JS modules directly?
These are JavaScript modules, updated doc comment
